did.head: Collection Summary

corpname.part: American Folklife Center, Library of Congress

did.abstract: Song texts, correspondence, publications, and fieldnotes collected by Robert Winslow Gordon.

processinfo.head: Processing History
processinfo.p: The Robert Winslow Gordon papers were processed by Sara Ludewig and Ying-Ting "Serena" Chiu in 2023. Some of the materials in Series 5 and Series 6 were treated by Grace Walters and Jennifer Evers in Conservation. Prior to processing in 2023, these papers received various rehousings, conservation treatments, and rearrangements.

relatedmaterial.p: Related materials in the Library of Congress's collections:

relatedmaterial.p:
Additional papers belonging to Robert Winslow Gordon, primarily folk songs collected by Gordon, can be found in the
Robert W. Gordon collection
at the University of Oregon Libraries, Special Collections and University Archives in Eugene, Oregon.

userestrict.head: Copyright Status
userestrict.p: Duplication of collection materials may be governed by copyright and other restrictions.

accessrestrict.head: Access and Restrictions
accessrestrict.p:
The Robert Winslow Gordon papers are open to research. To request materials, please contact the Folklife Reading Room at
https://hdl.loc.gov/loc.afc/folklife.contact
Certain restrictions to use or copying of materials may apply.

altformavail.head: Microfilm
altformavail.p:
A microfilm edition of the Robert Winslow Gordon papers is available on 15 reels in the Music Division at the Library of Congress. The collection is not duplicated in its entirety on microfilm and the arrangement of the physical papers has changed over time and no longer mirrors the arrangement of the papers on the microfilm. Researchers wishing to use the microfilm version of these materials should contact the Performing Arts Reading Room at
https://hdl.loc.gov/loc.music/perform.home

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Researchers wishing to cite this collection should include the following information: [item, date, container number], Robert Winslow Gordon papers (AFC 1928/003), American Folklife Center, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note
bioghist.p:
Robert Winslow Gordon was born in 1888 in Bangor, Maine. He studied English at Harvard beginning in 1906, working under George Lyman Kittredge. In 1912 he married Roberta Peter Paul of Darien, Gerogia, and their only child, a daughter named Roberta, was born in 1914. Gordon accepted a position as assistant professor of English at the University of California, Berkeley in 1917. During his tenure as a professor at the University of California between 1917 and 1924, Gordon collected over a thousand shanties and sea songs on the waterfront in San Francisco and Oakland. In 1923, Gordon began editing the column
Old Songs that Men Have Sung
in the pulp magazine
Adventure
. In the column, he printed songs requested by readers and asked readers to submit additional texts and verses, and in doing so built a robust collection of folk songs. In 1925, he embarked on a year-long research trip with the goal of creating the definitive collection of American folksong. During this time he collected songs in Asheville, North Carolina, and Darien, Georgia.

In 1928, the Librarian of Congress, Herbert Putnam, appointed Gordon as a "specialist and consultant in the field of Folk Song and Literature" in the Music Division. Later, Gordon adopted the title of director of the Archive of American Folk-Song. During this time, Gordon continued to live and conduct research in Darien, Georgia. In 1929, at the request of Putnam and Carl Engel, chief of the Music Division, Gordon concluded his fieldwork and moved to Washington, D.C. While in D.C., Gordon experimented with recording apparatuses and conducted his own tests with wax cylinders, wire recorders, and disc recorders. In 1933, dwindling funds and dissatisfaction with Gordon's performance led to the end of his tenure as the Director of the Archive of American Folk-Song. He continued to work as an editor and professor of English until he passed away in 1961.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p:
The collection comprises song texts, correspondence, publications, and field notes collected by Robert Winslow Gordon over the course of his career as a folklorist. The bulk of the collection includes correspondence and songs contributed by readers to the
Old Songs that Men Have Sung
column in
Adventures Magazine
, edited by Gordon. Also included are song texts from Gordon's fieldwork as well as song texts collected by others and given to Robert Winslow Gordon. Gordon also collected published music books, serials, magazines, and article reprints and these materials are included as part of his papers alongside his professional correspondence and field notes. Gordon spent the end of his life compiling and indexing his collection, and the card catalog song index he created is also included as part of the collection.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The Robert Winslow Gordon papers are organized in 8 series:

item.ref: Series 1: Correspondence and song texts contributed to the "Old Songs that Men Have Sung" column, Adventure Magazine, 1923-1929
Series 2: Song texts from fieldwork conducted by Robert Winslow Gordon, 1920-1925
Series 3: Song texts collected by others and acquired by Robert Winslow Gordon, 1922-1932
Series 6: Published serials, magazines, and reprints, 1840-1932 (bulk: 1910-1932)

controlaccess.head: Selected Search Terms
controlaccess.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the LC Catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject or location, and by occupation and listed alphabetically.

did.unittitle:
Series 1: Correspondence and song texts contributed to
Old Songs that Men Have Sung,
Adventure Magazine
,
1923-1929

scopecontent.p:
Approximately 3,858 letters containing songs and queries contributed to Robert Winslow Gordon in his role as editor of the
Old Songs That Men Have Sung
column in
Adventure Magazine
between 1923 and 1929.

did.unittitle:
Series 2: Song texts from fieldwork conducted by Robert Winslow Gordon,
1920-1925

scopecontent.p: Approximately 150 songs and groups of texts collected by Robert Winslow Gordon while he lived in California between 1920 and 1923. The first songs correspond with cylinder recordings 1-131.
Approximately 374 songs collected by Robert Winslow Gordon during a field trip to North Carolina between October and December 1925. Texts 1-298 correspond with cylinder recordings A1-A202.

did.unittitle: Original typescript, only recorded songs A1-A202

Series 3: Song texts collected by others and acquired by Robert Winslow Gordon,
1922-1932

scopecontent.p: Approximately 125 songs collected by J.P. Boyd in Alliance, North Carolina between 1926 and 1927.
Approximately 33 songs collected by R.M. Davids in Woodmere, Florida, circa 1924. Given to Robert Winslow Gordon by Joanna Colcord in New York, New York in December 1929.

Approximately 137 letters containing queries and songs for Robert Frothingham, editor of the
Old Songs that Men Have Sung
column of
Adventure Magazine
, 1922-1923 as well as correspondence to and from Frothingham while he was editor.
Approximately 8 songs collected by J.H. Hanford from Esther Stover in Cleveland, Ohio in January 1930. Stover learned the songs from her father in Iowa City, Iowa.

Approximately 61 southern Appalachian songs collected by Mellinger Edward Henry of Ridgewood, New Jersey in 1928-1929. Most texts and headnotes were subsequently published by Henry in the
Journal of American Folklore
and in
Folk-Songs from the Southern Highlands.

did.unittitle:
Subseries 6: Guy B. Johnson manuscripts,
circa 1929

scopecontent.p: Approximately 15 songs contributed by Guy B. Johnson of the University of North Carolina, circa 1929. Written down by Walter Jordon of New York, as he learned them in the American South in 1909.

Photostat manuscript entitled
Songs My Mother Sang,
containing 210 texts and 101 tunes from New Hope, Kentucky, contributed by Mary Newcomb of Louisville, Kentucky from 1929-1930.

did.unittitle:
Subseries 8: Howard W. Odum and J.D. Arthur manuscripts,
1929

scopecontent.p: Approximately 83 songs contributed by Howard W. Odum of the University of North Carolina in July 1929. Obtained by Odum from J.D. Arthur of Tennessee.
Approximately 22 songs contributed by R.W. Phillips of Akeley, Minnesota in March 1924.
Approximately 125 songs obtained from Betty Bush Winger of Point Pleasant, West Virginia, including traditional African American songs from Winger's home in the Ozark region of Missouri.

Bawdy songs taken from the
Adventure
, California, Georgia, and Davids manuscripts and indexed separately.
Published music collected by Robert Winslow Gordon, many of these publications are inscribed to Gordon by the composer.

title.part: Father of the Land We Love,

did.didnote: Includes: "Atlanta Blues," 1924; "Blind Man Blues," 1919; "The Chicago Gouge," 1924; "Deep River Blues," 1925; "Famous Comic Blues for the Ukulele," 1925; "The Gouge of Armour Avenue," 1924; "I'm Drinking from a Fountain That Never Runs Dry," 1925; "Joe Turner Blues," 1925; "John Henry Blues," 1922; "Harlem Blues," 1922; "Long Gone," 1920; "Loveless Love," 1921; "The Saint Louis Blues," 1924; "Stingaree Blues," 1924; "The Yellow Dog Blues," 1919.

scopecontent.p: Many of the pieces of sheet music are inscribed by W.C. Handy to Robert Winslow Gordon.

title.part: Howe's Eclectic School for the Flute,

title.part: Molineaux Collection of Sacred Music for Male Voices,
Music from the Days of George Washington,
The Music for Wakefield: A Folk-Masque,

did.didnote: Includes: "Bye and Bye," 1923; "Dear Heart of Mine," 1924; "Dear Old Southland," 1921; "De Clouds Are Gwine to Roll Away," 1924; "Don't Try to Cry Your Way Back to Me," 1925; "Down Hawaii Way," 1924.

scopecontent.p: Sheet music from various composers collected by Robert Winslow Gordon. Many of the pieces are inscribed by their composer to Gordon.

did.didnote: Includes: "Frankie and Johnny (You'll Miss Me in the Days to Come)," 1923; "Golden Memories (of Hawaii)," 1925; "Hinky Dinky Parlay Voo?," 1924; "Honolulu Rose," 1924.
Includes: "Swanee River Dreams," 1924; "Song Birds in Georgia," 1924; "Silver Sands of the Waikiki," 1925; "Stack O'Lee Blues," 1924; "Thunderstorm Blues," 1925.

Includes: "Unexpectedly," 1922; "Whistlin' the Blues Away," 1924; "When It's Love-Time in Hawaii," 1924; "Will You Remember (What I Can't Forget)," 1924; "What-cha-call-'em-Blues," 1925; "Will You Forget Me While I'm Away?," 1924; "Your Eyes," 1924.

scopecontent.p: Index of songs in the Robert Winslow Gordon collection. This card catalog was created by Gordon at the end of his career at the Library of Congress.
